Situation1: A dispatch call sends the ambulance driver through heavy city traffic to a location where a patient has a non-life-threatening injury.
Expectation2: Teach Torah and Jewish law to children and adults.
Situation2: The weekly required religious school class for children is set to occur.
Story: The radio crackled with a new dispatch just as I was reviewing my lesson plan for the children’s Torah class. “Non-life-threatening injury, downtown, heavy traffic,” the dispatcher said. I glanced at the clock—thirty minutes until I was supposed to stand before a room of eager young faces, ready to teach them the week’s parsha. My hands gripped the steering wheel as I navigated the ambulance through the congested streets, siren wailing, but my mind was split. As a driver, I was expected to get my patient to the hospital quickly, but above all, safely. Yet as a rabbi, I was expected to be present, to guide and inspire, to never let my students down. I could feel the weight of both uniforms pressing on my shoulders, the paramedic’s jacket and the rabbi’s tallit. Each role demanded my full attention, but I could not be in two places at once. My heart pounded with the impossible choice, torn between the duty to save and the duty to teach, as the city’s chaos pressed in around me.
